title: Reinforced Concrete Design
description: Design of reinforced concrete members based on serviceability and ultimate limit states. Design for combined shear and torsion. Review of one-way slabs and introduction to two-way slab systems. Design of two-way slabs using strip method, direct design method, and equivalent frame method. Punching of flat slabs, detailing of drop panels and capitals. Design of axial members subjected to axial load and uniaxial/biaxial bending. Slenderness effects. Non-sway and sway columns. Design of foundations subjected to axial and bending stresses. Introduction to walls, and design of bearing walls. Prerequisites: LE/CIVL 3230 3.00; LE/CIVL 3130 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Disruptive Technology Innovation & Entrepreneurship
description: Technology can create, reshape and destroy whole industries.  AirBnB, UBER, digital cameras and cell phones are some recent examples.  This course introduces concepts of how technology can create opportunities leading to new industries or disruption of existing industries.  Topics to be introduced include 3D printing, drones, robotics/automation, sensors, AI and big data, genomic sequencing, nanotech/advanced materials, microfluidics/microfabrication, energy storage/renewable energy/sustainability, blockchain and the internet of things. These topics are made accessible to students of non-technical disciplines.  Insights gained into tech disruption will be encapsulated within concepts of entrepreneurship to empower students to distinguish between technology hype vs reality and assist in forecasting future high-impact industry sectors.

title: Introduction to Microfluidics for Life Science Applications
titletranslation: Introduction to Microfluidics for Life Science Applications
description: This course builds on the foundation in measurement techniques by developing the students’ understanding of microfluidic techniques for biomedical applications. This course applies the classical knowledge of physics, chemistry biology and electrical engineering techniques to the development of microfluidic systems. Each microfluidic system includes two parts- micro-fabricated device and electrical device. In the design of each part of microfluidic device students are introduced the related theoretical and practical issues with a focus on needs assessment, creativity, and innovation as they seek to identify market opportunities. Topics include the design and implementation of microfluidic devices for various applications including electrophoresis, electrophoresis, electroporation cell counter; point-of-care (PoC) disease diagnostics applications. The students will learn the micro-fabrication soft lithography for biological application theoretically and practically. Prerequisites: LE/EECS 2210 3.00.

title: Fundamentals of Data Structures
description:
The course discusses the fundamental data structures commonly used in the design of algorithms. Abstract operations on data structures are specified using pre- and post-conditions and/or system invariants. Trade-offs between a number of different implementations of each abstract data types (ADT) are analyzed. Each algorithm operating on data structures is proved correct using loop invariants or induction. Both
formal and informal proofs are introduced, but most of the reasoning is done informally. Data structures are coded and unit tested in an object oriented language. Selecting the appropriate ADT and a suitable implementation depending on the application is covered. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS1019 3.00 or LE/EECS1028 3.00 or SC/MATH1019 3.00 or SC/MATH1028 3.00; LE/EECS1030 3.00 or LE/EECS2030 3.00. Course Credit Exclusion and previously offered as: LE/EECS 2011 3.00, LE/DIGT 2102 8.00, LE/EECS 2502 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Transportation Planning and Evaluation
description: This course introduces students to the major theories, principles and methods used in the field of transportation planning and evaluation. Under transportation planning, the course considers how transportation planners and decision-makers have historically analyzed the way people and goods move around cities. This includes an examination of the four-step travel demand model (the most widely used model) giving emphasis to the analytical techniques used to forecast future daily traffic demand on a roadway network. Under transportation project evaluation, the course presents fundamental concepts for the economic evaluation of roadway infrastructure improvement projects. Emphasis is placed on user and non-user costs with additional applications of lifecycle cost analysis, benefit-cost analysis, and the integration of these tools to support effective decision making. Prerequisites: LE/ENG 2001 3.00; LE/CIVL 3160 3.00 or LE/CIVL 3250 3.00. Course Credit Exclusion: LE/CIVL 4032 3.00.

title: Web-Centric Programming
description: CSSD1202 covers technologies and skills for full stack web and mobile programming, with a major focus on client-side development, and a smaller focus on server-side implementation. Topics include an introduction to network/Internet protocols; principles of layering, coding by design, and design by contract, particularly applied to web and mobile application architectures; event-driven programming, user interface design, layouts, and dynamic content; server-side model design; client- and server- side scripting; and interacting with data sources. Students will be informed to maintain a security mindset in their development process. Laboratory exercises expose students to a range of real-world problems with a view of enhancing computational thinking and grounding the material covered in lectures. In this journey, students will survey knowledge related to responsive design of full stack web and mobile application development and will learn at least one set of technologies more deeply to develop an industry- or community- inspired web/mobile project while improving skills in software versioning, debugging, and teamwork. The lectures are supplemented by a four-hour weekly lab. The project is developed using a simplified software development process with multiple stages, e.g., documentation/design/development/demonstration. The course promotes self-directed learning, coding by design, design by contract, principle of layering, pair programming or teamwork, use of APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), and enhancing students’ e-portfolios. Prerequisites: LE/CSSD 1050 3.00 or LE/CSSD 1101 3.00 or LE/CSSD 1102 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/DIGT 1302 3.00, LE/EECS 1012 3.00, AP/ITEC 3020 3.00.

title: Advanced Machine Learning
description: This course extends the introductory machine learning course to cover more advanced topics in machine learning. At the discretion of instructors, each course offering may select several advanced topics (at least three distinct topics in each offering) from, but not limited to, the following list: statistical learning theory, modern deep learning techniques, kernel methods, statistical models, deep generative models, Bayesian learning, graphical methods, reinforcement learning, meta learning, causal inference, differential privacy. Furthermore, the course also teaches how to apply and/or adapt these advanced machine learning methods to realistic settings in artificial intelligence such as computer vision, natural language processing, robotics, computer games and bioinformatics. Prerequisites: LE/EECS 2030 3.00; LE/EECS 3405 3.0 or LE/EECS 4404 3.00.

title: Data Structures for Data Science
description:
This course is designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to data structures and algorithms, including their design, analysis, and implementation. Initially, students become familiar with fundamental data structures (i.e., arrays and link lists) that are the building blocks for constructing all higher-level complex data structures. Then, recursion and algorithm analysis is covered. This course presents a subset of higher-level data structures that are more pertinent to data science by way of abstract data types. Trade-offs between a number of different implementations of each abstract data type (ADT) are analyzed. 
Prerequisites: LE/EECS 1019 3.00 or LE/EECS 1028 3.00 or SC/MATH 1019 3.00 or SC/MATH 1028 3.00; LE/EECS 1516 3.00. 
Course Credit Exclusion: LE/EECS 2011 3.00, LE/EECS 2101 3.00, LE/DIGT 2102 8.00.

title: Software I: Software Design and Architecture
description:
DIGT 3141 covers fundamental software engineering principles and development of skills for the design and implementation of software systems. Topics include basic principles of software development processes with emphasis on agile methods and test-driven development, and UML-based software design specification. The course introduces foundational software engineering principles related to the design of software systems, in-depth analysis of software systems architectural styles, design patterns, specification and design of APIs, antipatterns and antipattern detection strategies, refactoring, principles of distributed software architectures, metrics and standards for assessing software design quality assurance practices and communicating design decisions through software design models. 

Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 2107 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3311 3.00, LE/CSSD 2203 4.00.

title: Distributed Systems
description: DIGT 3203 aims to present the foundations of distributed systems. Its content is centered around four main areas: distributed systems architecture, inter-process communication and coordination, computer architecture, and the fundamentals of network communication for distributed computing. Students will learn to design and develop components that can communicate and coordinate with each other through a network, access data resources securely, and operate efficiently and reliably. Additionally, the course will explore how concepts previously encountered only in local contexts, such as data and operating systems, must be adapted for effective use in distributed environments. Throughout the course, students will gain practical experience by developing multi-threaded applications with concurrent data access in a distributed setting, utilizing services and resource virtualization. Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 2206 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 3211 3.0, LE/EECS 4222 3.00.

title: Introduction to Cloud Computing
description:
CSSD 2211 introduces the main concepts of modern cloud services and data centres. It outlines cloud services, including use of computation, storage, and networking resources, data engineering and analytics services, security and authentication, and others. It surveys the various cloud models, such as Infrastructure-as-a-Service, Platform-as-a-Service, Software-as-a-Service. It discusses quality of service concepts related to cloud computing including elasticity and scalability, availability and fault tolerance, performance, and security. Finally, it discusses cloud-related economic concepts, such as pricing schemes, cost analysis, and economies of scale. The main objective of the course is for students to acquire a firm grasp on the basic concepts of cloud computing, learn how to set up a cloud infrastructure, and how to deploy and use a software application on such an infrastructure. It is the first specialized course for students in the cloud computing streamThese skills are later enhanced in CSSD 3111 (Software Development for Cloud Computing) and CSSD 4211 (DevOps and SRE for Cloud Computing)

Throughout the term, students will practice these concepts in a team, where they will be asked to develop a simple multitier e-commerce application using the computation, storage and analytics services of a public cloud environment. Pre-requisites: LE/CSSD 2101 4.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Computer Science for Software Development (CSSD) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Introduction to Security
description:
CSSD 2221 provides an introduction to cybersecurity exploring security and digital safety concerns both from a user’s and from a system administrator’s perspective. It presents a holistic approach to system security covering human, organizational, and environmental aspects. Students will look at common security vulnerabilities included in comprehensive and longitudinal classifications such as OWASP and CWE. From an adversarial perspective, students will also learn how malicious software works, including viruses, malware, ransomware and others. They will learn how to recognize, detect, prevent, and patch these vulnerabilities, as well as to create threat models for them. They will also use fundamental testing and detection tools, including Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) Tools. They will explore basic notions of personal and system security including access control, authentication, data encryption and identity management. Moreover, students will review digital investigation methods as part of the software development lifecycle and software quality assurance and discuss the limitations of digital forensics.

Throughout the term, students will practice these concepts in small independent practical assignments individually or in small groups, where they will study small systems that have been intentionally developed with security vulnerabilities for training purposes. Students will analyze these systems for security vulnerabilities, provide reports and evaluations on their security and fix them by applying the appropriate mitigation techniques and patches.Pre-requisites: LE/CSSD 2101 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3482 3.00, LE/DIGT 2302 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Computer Science for Software Development (CSSD) - Lassonde School of Engineering

Students will learn how to conduct a digital investigation as part of the software development lifecycle.
Students will learn to appreciate the limitations of digital forensics.
CLO1: Discuss vulnerabilities in systems, including applications, operating systems, database systems and networks using classifications such as CWE
CLO2: Explain common frameworks for security management (such as NIST and ISO27001/27002)
CLO3: Identify threats and hazards using standard tools (such as an EDR tool) and create threat and trust models.
CLO4: Devise solutions to defend against viruses and other malicious programs.
CLO5: Explain the concepts of authentication, authorization, access control, and data integrity.
CLO6: Describe what a digital investigation is, the sources of digital evidence, and the limitations of forensics.

title: Introduction to Computing: A Net-centric Approach
titletranslation: Introduction to Computing: A Net-centric Approach
description:
The objectives of 1012 are threefold: providing a first exposure to event-driven programming, teaching students a set of computing skills (including reasoning about algorithms, tracing programs, test-driven development, unit testing), and providing an introduction to computing within a mobile, net-centric context. It uses problem-based approach to expose the underlying concepts and an experiential laboratory to implement them. A mature mobile software infrastructure 
(such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript) is used so that students can pick up key programming concepts (such as variables and control flow) within a client-server context without being bogged down in complex or abstract constructs. Laboratory exercises expose students to a range of real-world problems with a view of motivating computational thinking and grounding the material covered in lecture. Prerequisites: One of (1)-(3) below must be met: (1) (New high school curriculum): One 4U Math course with a grade of at least 75%. (2) Completion of six credits from York University MATH courses (not including courses with second digit 5) with a GPA of 5.00 or better over these credits; (3) Completion of six credits from York University mathematics courses whose second digit is 5, with an average grade not below 7.00 (B+). Course credit exclusions: AP/ITEC 3020 3.00, SC/CSE 2041 4.00 (prior to Summer 2013) Previously offered as: LE/CSE 2041 4.00, LE/EECS 2041 4.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Use a set of computing skills such as reasoning about algorithms, tracing programs, test-driven development, and diagnosing faults.
2. Explain and apply fundamental constructs in event-driven programs, including variables and expressions, control structures (conditionals/loops), and API usage.
3. Write simple programs using a given software infrastructure, API, and tool chain.
4. Gain exposure to net-centric computing, client-server applications, and simple relational database use.
5. Become familiar with the notion of syntax, both for programs and documents, and the principle of separation of concerns.

title: Computer Organization
description: Introduction to computer organization and instruction set architecture, covering assembly language, machine language and encoding, addressing modes, single/multicycle datapaths (including functional units and controls), pipelining, memory segments and memory hierarchy. title: Planetary Geophysics
description: This course analyzes the nature and usefulness of numerous geophysical tools for terrestrial and planetary exploration and in geologic observations. title: Computer Security Internship Work Term
description: This experiential education course reflects the work term component of the Technology Internship Program (TIP). Qualified Honours students gain relevant work experience as an integrated complement to their academic studies, reflected in the requirements of a learning agreement and work term report. Students are required to register in this course for each four month work term, with the maximum number of work term courses being four (i.e. 16 months). Students in this course receive assistance from the Career Centre prior to and during their internship, and are also assigned a Faculty Supervisor/Committee. Prerequisites: Enrolment is by permission only. Criteria for permission include: 1. that students have successfully completed at least 9.00 CSE credits at the 3000-level including LE/SC/CSE 3482 3.00, with a Grade Point Average (GPA) of at least 6.00 in all mathematics and computer science courses completed; 2. that students are enrolled full-time in the Honours program prior to beginning their internship and have attended the mandatory preparatory sessions as outlined by the Career Centre; 3. that students have not been absent for more than two consecutive years as a full-time student from their Honours degree studies; 4. that upon enrolling in this course students have a minimum of 9 credits remaining toward their Honours degree and need to return as a full-time student for at least one academic term to complete their degree after completion of their final work term. Note: This is a pass/fail course, which does not count for degree credit. Registration in LE/SC/CSE 3980 0.00 provides a record on the transcript for each work term.

titletranslation: Introduction to Machine Learning and Pattern Recognition

outcomes.value: Learn to develop powerful pattern recognition algorithms.

Program moderately complex machine learning algorithms

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: This is a second course in Artificial intelligence that covers selected topics in this area such as: reasoning about action and planning, uncertain and fuzzy reasoning, knowledge representation, automated reasoning, non-monotonic reasoning and answer set programming, ontologies and description logic, local search methods, Markov decision processes, autonomous agents and multi-agent systems, machine learning, reasoning about beliefs and goals, and expert systems. title: Analog Integrated Circuit Design
description:
This course presents analog circuit principles for the analysis and design of high-performance circuits in modern technologies. Its techniques enable the realization of wide-band amplifiers, low-noise amplifiers, operational amplifiers, and feedback amplifiers. Advanced computer simulation, and
physical layout are presented.Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 3611 4.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Characterize and abstract the behavior of modern electronic devices into compact models for the purpose of analog circuit design.
2. Understand and design open-loop and feedback amplifiers taking frequency-domain considerations into account.
3. Understand and implement stabilization techniques for feedback amplifiers.
4. Analyze and design wideband amplifiers and operational amplifiers, including their physical implementation.
5. Verify the behavior of high‐performance designs using simulation and experimental techniques.
1. Identify the key electronic and physical features of devices in modern semiconductor technology.
2. Extract key figures of merit from semiconductor device models
3. Compute the frequency response of feedforward and feedback compensated feedback systems.
4. Identify, design, and verify key feedback strategies in modern wide‐band multistage amplifier topologies including operational transconductance amplifiers and folded cascade amplifiers.
5. Derive the noise transfer functions through modern multi‐stage low‐noise amplifier topologies.
6. Identify, design, and verify low‐noise amplifier circuitry.
7.Analyze and design the physical implementation of wideband and operational amplifiers based on given design rules.

title: Computational Complexity
description: Study of time and space and other computational resources required for efficient solution of classes of computational problems, including P and NP, PSPACE. Proof techniques including diagonalization, simulation, reduction and completeness. Models of computation, nondeterminism, randomness. Intractability. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 1030 3.00; LE/EECS 2001 3.00; LE/EECS 3101 3.00. title: Medical Imaging Systems
description: This course will provide an introduction to several of the major imaging modalities ranging from X-ray projection radiography to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  This course applies the classical knowledge of physics, circuits, and signal and systems techniques to the development of medical imaging systems. Background in medical devices, electronic circuit, signal and systems, basic knowledge of human physiology and body system, and basic knowledge of physics are required before taking the course. Topics include the physics of radiography; fundamental of X-ray projection radiography and X-ray computed tomography (CT); Fundamental of ultrasound imaging techniques and ultrasound imaging systems; and introduction of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) system. Three lecture hours per week.  Three laboratory hours per week.  Prerequisites:  General Prerequisite; LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 1030 3.00; LE/ EECS 2210 3.00, LE/EECS 3602 4.00 or LE/EECS 3451 4.00. (NOTE: The General Prerequisite is a cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses.  EECS courses with the second digit "5" are not major courses.)

outcomes.value: The primary objective will be on developing the student's ability to integrate and apply their knowledge in electronic circuits and physiological systems        he design of medical devices and bio-instruments. Specifically, students will:

• Employ medical imaging  systems  and  apply  low  complexity  image processing techniques.

description: Coordinate systems, conventions and transformations. First and second geodetic problems: trig sections, traverses, areas, volumes. Basics of random error theory and error propagation. title: Professional Development for Co-Op Students
description:
Developing an effective e‐Portfolio for Lassonde co‐op students as a tool for professional development and job finding. Learning from, and adapting to, the transition from university to the workplace. Offered online. Estimated time in required learning activities: 3 hours per week. Prerequisites: Enrolment in the Lassonde Co‐op Option, requiring a GPA of 5.0 and completion of: 
- Engineering: 60 credits of core engineering courses, of which at least 30 credits must be at the 2000‐level and include LE/ENG 1101 4.00, LE/ENG 1102 4.00, and LE/ENG 2001 3.00.  
- Honours Earth Science, Atmospheric Science: Completion of 50 credits including all core 1000 and 2000 level courses required for the relevant Honours stream.
- Honours Computer Science or Computer Security: Completion of 50 credits, including at least four of the 2000‐level EECS core courses (EECS 2001, EECS 2011, EECS 2021, EECS 2030, EECS 2031, EECS 2101). 
- Honours Digital Media: 50 credits, including at least four of the 2000-level Digital Media core courses (DATT 2100, DATT 2040, DATT 2050, EECS 2030, EECS 2101, EECS, 2031, EECS 2311).
To qualify, the student must have attended all mandatory preparatory sessions required by the Lassonde Co‐op Stream. This course must be taken during the student's first work‐term. Co‐requisites: LE/COOP 2109 0.0 Lassonde Coop Work‐term.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Cooperative Education (COOP) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Geodetic Surveys
description: Instrument systems and procedures for high-precision geodetic surveys. High-precision surveys in engineering physics; geodetic network densification, adjustment and analysis; procedures for deformation surveys and strain analysis. Establishment and observation of control networks for construction and monitoring of large engineering structures. Three lecture hours and three hours of laboratory exercises hours per week. One term. Four credits. title: Heat Transfer and Thermal Design
description:
This course covers the fundamentals of heat transfer and thermodynamics, the methods and tools for thermal control and design, and their application in space engineering. Prerequisites: SC/MATH 2271 3.00; SC/CHEM 1100 4.00; SC/PHYS 1801 3.00.

Date of Submission: 2018-02-06
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Perform calculations for 1D and 2D heat conduction in steady and unsteady conditions.
2. Perform radiation heat transfer calculations based on Stefan-Boltzmann law and viewfactors.
3. Describe the operating principles and model the performance of thermal devices used on spacecraft such as heat pipes, radiators, MLI, thermoelectrics coolers, etc.
4. Apply conduction and radiation theory to the modelling of a spacecraft in orbit and in test.

title: Electro-Optics
description: This course builds on the foundations of electromagnetic theory and wave propagation to teach fundamentals of optical propagation in solids and light- matter interaction. Topics include light propagation in crystals & optical fibers, polarization, semiconductors, light generation & detection, lasing, optical modulation and nonlinear optics. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"), LE/EECS 3604 4.00 or SC/PHYS 4020 3.00, LE/EECS 2210 3.00 or SC/PHYS 3150 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Demonstrates understanding of light propagation in matter and  interfaces, and can numerically simulate the behavior in multilayers
2.  Demonstrates understanding of light polarization and guiding, and can design means  to control them
3. Comprehends light absorption and emission, and the necessary conditions for light amplification
4.     Comprehends the basics of semiconductor lasers operation and design
5.Understand how to combine the constraints for higher harmonic generation through practical design
6. Demonstrates the ability to combine several  electro‐optical building blocks by designing waveguide‐based or waveguide‐coupled lasers, photoreceivers and modulators
7.     Demonstrates practical hands‐on skills in applying in the lab the principles thought in  class
1. Demonstrate an understanding of optical wave propagation in free, bound and anisotropic media, thereby assimilating the associated science and mathematical principles
2. Demonstrate knowledge of the design principles involved in engineering waveguides, compensation of distortions in pulse propagation through optical fibers, and light modulation

3.     Demonstrate an understanding of the differences between spontaneous and stimulated light emission, and the basic semiconductor theory  underlying the operation of detectors and light emitting diodes.
4.     Demonstrate the ability to design and components using analytical, numerical or engineering tools
5.     Demonstrate the team work necessary to successfully coordinate experiments in practical laboratory demonstrations

title: Remote Sensing of the Earth's Surface
titletranslation: Remote Sensing of the Earth's Surface
description: Principles used in extracting physical information about the Earth's surface using remote sensing. Remote sensing in the visible, short-wave infrared, thermal infrared and microwave regions is discussed in terms of potential applicability to forestry, agriculture, water resources and geology. Two lecture hours, three laboratory hours. One term. Three credits. Prerequisite(s): SC/PHYS 2020 3.00, or SC/PHYS 2060 3.00, or both SC/PHYS 2211 1.00 and SC/PHYS 2212 1.00.

title: Introduction to Structural Design
description: Provides a review of: basic structural systems, including gravity and lateral load-resisting systems; principles of Limit States Design according to the National Building Code (NBC) of Canada; and dead and live loads, snow and rain loads, and loads due to wind based on the NBC. Properties of structural steel and reinforced concrete will be discussed. Design of structural steel including tension members, compression members, beams, and connections will be based on CSA S16. Design of reinforced concrete according to CSA A23.3 will include: beams in flexural and shear; and columns under axial load, and combined axial load and bending. Prerequisites: LE/CIVL 2120 3.00, LE/CIVL 3130 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Traffic Simulation Modelling
description: CIVL 4033 Traffic Simulation Modelling will teach the principles, theories, and application processes of traffic simulation modelling for 4th year Civil Engineering students to understand the complex interactions between traffics and surface infrastructure system. This course covers a variety of topics related to traffic simulation modelling such as car following and gap acceptance theories and swept path analysis. This course also provides students the opportunity to learn how to use the state-of-the-industry simulation tools (e.g., VISSIM, AutoTURN) to make informed decisions on the various surface infrastructure improvement projects. Prerequisites: LE/CIVL 3250 3.00 or LE/CIVL 3260 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

description: The course emphasizes the basic concepts of structural analysis and introduces computer-aided analytical techniques. Prerequisites:LE/CIVL 2220 3.00 or LE/CIVL 2220 4.00

title: Coding through Chemistry (CS1 B)
description: Introduction to fundamentals of procedural programming in the context of chemistry. The lecture component is in two parts: some lectures focus on computer programming skills, and other lectures focus on selected topics from chemistry. The laboratory component allows students to strengthen computing skills and understanding of the chemistry concepts through computer simulations and problem solving. Through this experiential journey, students will learn the fundamentals of programming, computational problem solving, as well as the software development process. This course typically runs from week 7 to week 12 of the term. CSSD1101 and CSSD1102 both cover fundamental programming concepts and are meant to reinforce each other by covering those concepts in two different contexts. Course credit exclusions: LE/DIGT 1101 4.00, LE/EECS 1012 3.00, LE/EECS 1015 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Computer Science for Software Development (CSSD) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: In this course, the students will learn: • a set of computing skills such as designing basic algorithms, tracing algorithms and programs, and behaviour-driven development.

a set of technical knowledge such as software development process, the principle of layering, coding by design, design by contract, the notion of syntax, as well as software documentation and teamwork using an e-portfolio.

fundamental constructs in programs—including variables and expressions, control structures (conditionals/loops, recursion)—as well as professional development environments (such as version control systems and IDEs) towards developing simple programs.

selected Chemistry concepts with scientific meaning and appropriate context. • tools and strategies for making predictions for selected Chemistry experiments via computer simulations or interactive programs.
experience of effectively and collegially working with others in the laboratory and class setting.
CLO1: Design and trace basic algorithms and procedural programs.
CLO2: Apply design principles to the software development process.

title: Computer Networks
description: This course allows students to understand how computer networks are put together, how they work, how applications use them, and what the underlying fundamental principles are that allow developers to build and design applications using computer networks. The course focuses on the design of programs that use computer networks; the terminology associated with networking; the key paradigms and strategies used in developing applications that use computer networks; the basic concepts of how the Internet is put together and operates; and the basic protocols that are used in the TCP/IP architecture. The material will be framed by looking at the key strategies and models for addressing scalability and reliability; layers and abstractions; routing, naming, and addressing; isolation, data loss, and performance; and privacy and security. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 1302 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3214 3.00, LE/CSSD 3106 2.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Students will learn how to use tools like sockets to design programs that communicate with other systems on the Internet.
Students will learn the design principles and the different layers and abstractions of the TCP/IP architecture.
Students will learn how to read and interpret a formal specification (such as an RFC) for a protocol, and how to apply this specification in practical applications.

Students will learn the difference between reliable transport (e.g., TCP) and best-effort transport (e.g., UDP), including concepts like congestion control, flow control, and how to apply this knowledge in practical applications.
Students will learn the hierarchy of Internet entities such as networks and autonomous systems, and the implications of the organization of the Internet in routing decisions.
Students will learn how to use protocols that address basic principles of confidentiality, integrity and authentication in Internet communication.
Students will learn how to measure network performance in metrics like latency and bandwidth, as well as to identify bottlenecks and sources of congestion.
CLO1: Design and maintain programs that communicate with other systems using computer networks, including sockets.
CLO2: Describe the different parts of the TCP/IP architecture, including their functionality, strengths and weaknesses, and the design principles used in their construction.
CLO3: Apply the formal specification of protocols such as HTTP and DNS in the implementation of network applications.
CLO4: Contrast the service models and features of transport layer protocols, including flow and congestion control, and properly use an appropriate protocol according to a system’s need.
CLO5: Describe the requirements and trade-offs involved in routing within an Autonomous System and between separate Autonomous Systems.
CLO6: Use appropriate protocols to address confidentiality, integrity, and end-point authentication while considering the security limitations of communication on the Internet.
CLO7: Measure and address common performance concerns, particularly related to processing, queueing, transmission, and propagation delays.

title: Technology Leadership & Professional Reflection 4
description:
This course introduces foundational concepts and practices of leadership and reflection, and develops students’ skills needed to succeed and thrive in technology-oriented programs and in technology and computing related fields.  Students will develop the cognitive, emotional, and relational foundations for learning, thriving, leadership, and contribution with emphasis on learning from students’ professional and academic experience through reflection frameworks.   

This course is the last of four courses in a course series (1.0 credit each). Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 3271 1.00.

outcomes.value: To help students develop the cognitive, emotional, and relational foundations for learning, thriving, and meaningful leadership.
To help students apply these learnings in their personal, professional, and academic lives.
To guide students in critical reflection and holistic self-development based on these learnings and their lived experiences.

Throughout the four courses, to have students reflect on: 1. What is the value of (lifelong) learning? 2. What does it mean to be a good student? 3. What does it mean to be a good professional (e.g. software developer, engineer, etc)?  4. How can technological professionals align their career with a purposeful and fulfilling life?

title: Programming in C
description: In this course, students will learn the C programming language. This language will expose students to concepts that are closely related to machine language constructs. Students will be introduced to concepts typically hidden in higher level languages, such as memory management, representation of data in memory, and pointer arithmetic. Students are also introduced to dynamic memory allocation concepts, as well as common memory management challenges such as explicit deallocation, dangling pointers and memory leaks, along with best practices to address these issues. The duration of this course is typically 6 weeks, running from the middle of week 2 to the middle of week 8. Pre-requisites: LE/CSSD 1201 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/DIGT 2103 4.00, LE/EECS 2031 3.00.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning I
description: DIGT3131 is the first course of the Introduction to Machine Learning series (DIGT 3131 and DIGT 3231). DIGT3131 and DIGT 3231 together present the fundamentals of machine learning. DIGT3131 covers basic mathematical concepts, introduces machine learning principles and supervised learning with a focus on regression. Students will learn to implement and evaluate regression algorithms using Python and libraries like Scikit-learn, applying these algorithms to real-world datasets. Emphasis will also be placed on model evaluation and ethical considerations in machine learning, including fairness and transparency. This course aims to prepare students for topics in machine learning in DIGT3231, and to foster a responsible and ethical approach to the development and deployment of machine learning models. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 2201 3.00. Credit credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3404 3.00, LE/EECS 3405 3.00, LE/CSSD 3131 3.00, LE/CSSD 3231 3.00.

title: Software II: Software Testing and Quality Assurance
description:
DIGT 3241 aims to introduce key techniques and tools for testing software systems at unit level, subsystem level, and application level as well as techniques to assess and quantify the quality of a software component or a software application as a whole.  This course covers topics in black box unit testing, white box unit testing, grey box testing, elements of data flow analysis, object-oriented systems testing, model-driven testing, bottom-up, top-down and meet-in-the-middle integration testing, functional testing and, acceptance testing. In addition to the above, the course will cover topics related to different perspectives of load and penetration testing software quality, software metrics, code walkthroughs, and software reliability growth models.

 Students will learn to design test cases at all phases of the testing life cycle (unit, integration, functional, acceptance), use standard frameworks to test a software system, and evaluate the quality and reliability of a software system using code analysis and reliability growth models. 
Throughout the term, students will gain practical experience by designing and applying test plans and test cases on medium size systems, evaluate the testing effort, and quantify the impact testing and code walkthroughs have on increasing system quality and reliability.

 Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 2107 3.00. Co-requisites: LE/DIGT 3141 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 3203 3.00, LE/EECS 4313 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Building Science Principles and Applications
description: This course teaches the fundamentals of building physics, including heat transfer, moisture transport, and air movement. Using these fundamentals, the design of the building envelope such as walls, roofs, and foundations are taught from both a performance and durability aspect. The course presents sustainable building design techniques and case studies. Laboratory components are used to illustrate materials and performance testing commonly used in building envelope evaluations. Basic 2D heat flow simulation will be taught. Prerequisites: LE/CHEM 1100 4.00, LE/CIVL 2120 3.00, LE/CIVL 3140 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: The overall goals are to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of heat, moisture, and air movement through the building envelope. title: Introduction to Computer Organization & Systems
description: DIGT 2103 introduces the basics of computer organization and systems. Topics include access to memory through implicit and explicit memory references, data segment, program, heap, and stack; fetch-execute cycle; translating data access, logic and code blocks written in highlevel languages and translated into Assembly language; memory management bugs, dangling pointers, memory leaks, and best practices in memory management; implementation of program features such as functions and polymorphism in a hardware model; performance in CPUs, pipelining, and memory caching. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 1201 8.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 2103 0.50, LE/CSSD 2104 2.00, LE/CSSD 2105 1.00, LE/CSSD 2106 0.50, LE/EECS 2021 4.00, LE/EECS 2031 3.00.

title: Software Development Lifecycle
description: This course introduces the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) which covers a comprehensive study of the processes, methodologies, and best practices employed in developing high-quality software. Some of the methodologies are, among others, Agile, Waterfall, and Iterative. The course equips students with the knowledge and skills necessary to navigate the entire software development journey, from inception, specification, coding, testing, to deployment and maintenance. By exploring different SDLC methodologies and understanding each phase’s significance, students will be well-prepared to contribute effectively to real-world software projects. title: Network Security
description: This course extends the discussion of network security covered by DIGT 2206, focusing on how network protocols, applications and platforms implement confidentiality, authentication, integrity, privacy, access and availability. Students are presented with both theoretical discussions of network security fundamental principles, but also with practical applications of these principles in real-life protocols and applications. Strategies used to provide security in network environments are evaluated in the context of scalability and reliability, layers and abstractions, isolation and performance. Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 2206 3.00, LE/DIGT 2302 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 3221 3.00.

title: Security by Design
description: DIGT 3221 focuses on security by design. The course integrates software design principles with security concerns. The course's objective is to let the student understand the importance of guaranteeing the security of digital systems as early as a project's design phase. Students will review software design principles and design patterns and how these can be applied to ensure security. They will also recognize security antipatterns and learn how to resolve them by refactoring the design of the system. They will also learn how to do threat modeling in parallel with designing the system. Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 2302 3.00

title: Digital Technologies Project
description: DIGT 3171 is a comprehensive, year-long capstone course designed for third-year students in the Digital Technologies Program. Spanning the fall, winter, and summer terms, this 9-credit course offers students a unique opportunity to apply their theoretical knowledge to a full-sized project, potentially integrated with their current workplace. Through designing, implementing, and managing a significant digital technology project, students will enhance their professional skills, including problem-solving, communication, and project management, while gaining valuable insights into industry trends. This course culminates in a final presentation and comprehensive documentation, equipping students with a portfolio piece that showcases their expertise and readiness for a professional career in digital technologies. Pre-requisites : LE/DIGT 2107 3.00

title: The Earth Environment
description:
Provides essential topics in Earth environment (Earth and oceanic science, atmospheric science, and geology) and explores the
role played by global and local scale processes in shaping our planet. Concepts are described; the latest technology discussed, and links
between engineering disciplines are provided. The course lectures are complemented by hands-on laboratory and field experience.
Prerequisites: 12U calculus and vectors or 12U advanced functions, or SC/MATH 1515 3.00; 12U physics or SC/PHYS 1510 4.00.
Corequisites: LE/ENG 1101 4.00; LE/ENG 1102 4.00; SC/PHYS 1800 3.00, SC/PHYS 1801 3.00.

title: Advanced Power Electronic Applications
description: The objective of this course is to understand the operating principles of several different advanced power electronic converters and their applications.  The basic AC/DC rectifiers, DC/DC switch mode converters, voltage source DC/AC inverters and resonant converters are first reviewed.  Various combinations of power converters and inverters and their applications will then be discussed, topics include: passive and active power factor correction circuits, converters and inverters for renewable energy systems, motor drive circuits, converters for battery chargers and telecom systems, bi-directional converters used in uninterruptible power supply (UPS), high frequency inverters for lighting applications and induction heating.  Computation of circuit quantities such as average and RMS value, average power, power factor, total harmonics distortion and power efficiency are also studied in each of the above topics. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.5 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit of "5"); LE/EECS 4613 4.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

5. Introduce power electronic converter circuits for real-life applications.

title: Digital Very Large Scale Integration
description: An introductory course on the design of VLSI CMOS chips. Key elements of complex digital system design are presented including nanoscale MOS fundamentals, CMOS combinational and sequential logic design, datapath and control system design, memories, testing, packaging, l/O, scalability, reliability, and IC design economics. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5");  LE/EECS 2200 3.00, LE/EECS 2210 3.00, LE/EECS 3201 4.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1.   Demonstrate knowledge of contemporary VLSI design  methodology and be able to cogently describe the main steps of a VLSI design flow.
2. Demonstrate the ability to approximate the physical size of an integrated VLSI circuit given sufficient structural and technological information.

3. Discuss contemporary VLSI design IC technologies (fabrication, structure, and applications) and be able to mathematically acticulate how they workr and what their electronic capabilities and drawbacks are.
4.  Demonstate the ability to simplify advanced IC technologies into basic circuit models capable of providing sufficient approximations for first-order digital circuit analysis.
5.    Demonstrate the ability to optimize a variety of digital circuits for energy-delay  performance.

6. Demonstrate the ability to design and synthesize semi-custom hardware sub-systems such as state machines, memories, logic arrays, busses, etc. in a modern IC technology from a library of standard cells.
7.      Demonstrate the ability to apply hardware design languages for the realization of  complete through hands-on practice with non-trivial (greater than 10,000 gates) examples and custom designs.

8. Refining the ability to analyze the performance of VLSI systems using established criteria such as latency, throughput, operational energy consumption as well as newly emphasized issues such as power management and clock distribution.
9.    Demonstrate an understanding of the means of verifying the operation of complex digital ICs.
10.  Gaining expertise with state-of-the-art custom IC design tools.
11. Create a practical VLSI project work plan and meet designated deadlines towards that plan. Effectively communicate a personal design in person and in the form of a written  report.

title: Systems and Random Processes in Discrete Time
titletranslation: Systems and Random Processes in Discrete Time
description: Discrete signals are obtained by sampling continuous signals. Starting with a continuous time signal, the course reviews the concept of a discrete signal, the conditions under which a continuous signal is completely represented by its discrete version, and discusses the analysis and design of linear time-invariant, discrete-time systems. In particular, frequency selective filters in the discrete time domain are developed. The second half of the course will cover advanced topics of random processes, noise, and their applications in the real world including the effect of linear systems on the statistical properties of random signals. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 2602 4.00, LE/CSE 2602 4.00; SC/MATH 2930 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3451 4.00, LE/CSE 3451 4.00, SC/CSE 3451 4.00).

title: Computer Security Internship Work Term
description: This experiential education course reflects the work term component of the Technology Internship Program (TIP). Qualified Honours students gain relevant work experience as an integrated complement to their academic studies, reflected in the requirements of a learning agreement and work term report. Students are required to register in this course for each four month work term, with the maximum number of work term courses being four (i.e. 16 months). Students in this course receive assistance from the Career Centre prior to and during their internship, and are also assigned a Faculty Supervisor/Committee. Prerequisites: Enrolment is by permission only. Criteria for permission include: 1. that students have successfully completed at least nine EECS or CSE credits at the 3000-level including LE/EECS 3482 3.00 or LE/CSE 3482 3.00 or SC/CSE 3482 3.00, with a GPA of at least 6.00 in all mathematics and computer science courses completed; 2. that students are enrolled full-time in the Honours program prior to beginning their internship and have attended the mandatory preparatory sessions as outlined by the Career Centre; 3. that students have not been absent for more than two consecutive years as a full-time student from their Honours degree studies; 4. that upon enrolling in this course students have a minimum of nine credits remaining toward their Honours degree and need to return as a full-time student for at least one academic term to complete their degree after completion of their final work term. Registration in LE/EECS 3980 0.00 (formerly LE/CSE 3980 0.00, SC/CSE 3980 0.00) provides a record on the transcript for each work term.

title: Payload Design
description:
This course provides students with a comprehensive and accurate approach for the specification and detailed design of different spacecraft payloads, including optical payload, microwave payload, communications payload, and planetary exploration payload. Reliability analysis and its application will also be covered for space systems. Payload design projects will be assigned to students during the course. Three lecture hours per week. Prerequisites: LE/ENG 2001 3.00, LE/ESSE 3280 3.00

Date of submission: 2013-12-03 (Added most recent prerequisites from 2018-02-06)
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. A knowledge base for engineering The course provides a foundation in the systems engineering method (specialized engineering knowledge) appropriate for designing spacecraft payloads. The achievement is evaluated through demonstration of application in the design project as well as in the assignments and final examination.

2. Design The design of a spacecraft payload naturally includes the solution of a complex and poorly bounded engineering problem. The emphasis is on identifying specific needs or mission objectives and requirements, constraints, etc.

3. Individual and teamwork The course provides individual assessment through assignments and final examination component. The design project provides an assessment on a group basis with the project requiring the demonstration of fundamental science and engineering knowledge, project management, systems engineering and subsystem design skills.

4. Communication Skills Communication skills are demonstrated and evaluated during project reviews. These reviews are oral presentations with all team members presenting their contribution to the project. The reviews are evaluated by the objectives for the review and by a question and answer process from the course director and the students from other groups. In total, there will be three presentations during the design period, i.e. preliminary design presentation, detailed design presentation and final design presentation. Written communication is evaluated in the assessment of the written group project report.

5. Impact of engineering on society and the environment The design project requires the understanding of the benefit of the space mission goals on society and must be justified from a cost/benefit perspective.
6. Economics and project management The students are expected to organize their project in a project management formalism that is presented to them in the lecture component.

title: Introduction to Medical Devices and Biological Instruments
titletranslation: Introduction to Medical Devices and Biological Instruments
description: This course builds on the foundation in measurement techniques by developing the students' understanding of electrophysiological sensing systems and biosensors used within the medical and biological fields. This course applies the classical knowledge of electronic circuits and systems techniques to the development of medical devices and biological instruments. Background in electronic circuit design, basic knowledge of human physiology and body system, and basic knowledge of cellular and molecular biology are required before taking the course. Topics include the design of medical devices such as Electro-Encephalography (EEG) and Electromyography (EMG) devices used for disease diagnostics; biological instruments such as cell counter; handheld sensing devices used for various point-of-care (PoC) applications such as glucose measurement, blood pressure monitoring and early detection of cancer; and wearable sensing devices used for fitness applications. In the design of each medical device or biological instrument, students are also introduced the related theoretical and practical issues with a focus on needs assessment, creativity, and innovation as they seek to identify market opportunities. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"), LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 1030 3.00, LE/EECS 2210 4.00, LE/EECS 3215 4.00, SC/BIOL 1000 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: The primary objective will be on developing the student's ability to integrate and apply their knowledge in electronic circuits and physiological systems in the design of medical devices and bio-instruments. Specifically, students will:
• Develop an understanding of electrical measurement techniques including EEG, EMG and ECG.
• Develop an understanding of biosensors and point-of-care techniques  used for early detection or control of diseases such as diabetes and cancer.
• Develop an understanding of biological instruments such as cell counter, biological electrical activities' recording and stimulation
•  Be able to analyze and design biomedical measurement systems.
• Develop an understanding of the safety and regulatory issues pertinent to medical devices
• Develop an understanding of advanced technologies such as microfluidics and Lab-on-Chips.

title: Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and Data Integration
titletranslation: Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and Data Integration
description: Project-oriented geomatics course using GIS systems (Arc/Info and S-PLus or SPSS for UNIX) and various techniques (map algebraic, statistical, fuzzy logic, AI, neural network and fractal/multifractal) for integrating diverse dataset (geological, geophysical, geochemical, remote sensing and GPS). Two lecture hours, two laboratory hours. One term. Three credits. Prerequisite: One of LE/ESSE 3300 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 3180 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 4340 3.00, ES/ENVS 3520 3.00, ES/ENVS 4520 3.00, or permission of the instructor.   Prior to Fall 2014: Prerequisite: One of LE/EATS 3300 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 3180 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 4340 3.00, ES/ENVS 3520 3.00, ES/ENVS 4520 3.00, or permission of the instructor.  Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisite: One of SC/EATS 3300 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 3180 3.00, AP/SC/GEOG 4340 3.00, ES/ENVS 3520 3.00, ES/ENVS 4520 3.00, or permission of the instructor.

title: Professional Development for Co-Op Students
description: Developing an effective e-Portfolio for engineering co-op students as a tool for professional development and job finding. Learning from, and adapting to, the transition from university to the workplace.  Prerequisites: Enrolment in the Engineering Co-op Stream, requiring a GPA of 5.0 and completion of 60 credits of core engineering courses, of which at least 30 credits must be at the 2000-level and include ENG 1000 and ENG 2001 (or equivalent). To qualify, the student must have attended all mandatory preparatory sessions required by the Engineering Co-op Stream. This course must be taken during the student's first work-term. Co-requisites: LE/SC COOP 2001 0.0 Co-op Work-term.

title: Software Development Project
description: This course allows students to develop a significant piece of software utilizing all the skills they have acquired so far. This includes requirement elicitation, system specification, implementation, testing, deployment, and user documentation. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 1030 3.00 or LE/EECS 2030 3.00. Course Credit Exclusion: LE/DIGT 2107 3.00.

title: Sedimentology and Structural Geology
description: Weathering, clastic rocks, diagenesis, mudrocks, carbonates, evaporites, orthographic construction, structural contours, stereographic projection, faults, folds, fabric analysis. Normally offered in alternate years. Three lecture hours, three laboratory hours. One term. Four credits. Prerequisites: LE/EATS 2030 3.00; LE/EATS 2050 4.00. Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisites: SC/EATS 2030 3.00; SC/EATS 2050 4.00.

title: Electronic Circuits and Devices
description: This course covers the basic material required in the design of both analog and digital electronic circuits. Diodes, transistors (both BJT and FET), amplifiers, rectifiers. title: Mission-Critical Systems
description: Theory and practical tools underlying deductive and algorithmic methods for ensuring the safety and correctness of mission critical systems (e.g. medical systems, nuclear reactors and train systems) with the practical ability to use verification tools to perform software certification. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour per week. One term. Three credits. Prerequisites: General prerequisites; LE/CSE 3311 3.00, and LE/CSE 3342 3.00. Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisites: General prerequisites; SC/CSE 3311 3.00, and SC/CSE 3342 3.00.

title: System Specification and Refinement
description: Theory and tools for specifying computer systems (sequential, concurrent and embedded). Specification (via set theory and predicate logic), modelling, abstraction, refinement and formal reasoning are undertaken before code development so that systems are correct by construction under the stated assumptions. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour per week. One Term. Three credits. Prerequisites: General prerequisites and SC/MATH 1090 3.00.

title: Signals and Systems

title: Advanced Topics in Remote Sensing
description: The course offers an in-depth coverage of the emerging sensing technologies and advanced analysis methods in Earth observations research and applications. It is built on the fundamentals of remote sensing science and technology introduced in ESSE 4220 (Remote sensing of Earth’s surface, offered in the 3rd year) and ESSE 4630 (Image processing for remote sensing and photogrammetry). This course focuses on the extraction of information related to human and physical environment for applications including but not limited to agriculture, land use, forestry, urban and rural planning, geology, and resource management. It enables students to design methods and implement algorithms to support these applications using advanced remote sensing approaches. Prerequisites: EECS 1021 3.00, ESSE 3600 3.00, and ESSE 4630 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Explain principles and apply emerging technologies for Earth observations.
2. Design work flows for a range of information extraction methods to support applications such as precision agriculture, precision forestry, environmental monitoring, and urban development etc.
3. Develop and implement algorithms to derive information from remotely sensed data.
1. Explain and describe the technical principles behind each topic covered in this course and how they are applied to solve real world problems.
2. Identify and explain current developments and open questions in each topic.
3. Identify, assess and process the necessary data for a given remote sensing problem.
4. Design, develop, modify and implement algorithms and data flows for a given problem.
5. Complete projects within the course topics, present the results and discuss critical issues

title: Photogrammetry
description: Image and object space. Direct and inverse problems of projective and similarity coordinate transformations. Collinearity and coplanarity. Orientation procedures. Measurement and correction of image coordinates. Stereomodel formation and error analysis. Analog, analytical, independent model, strip and block adjustments. Image rectification. DEM generation. Digital Mapping Applications. Project planning. Three lecture hours and three hours of laboratory exercises per week. One term. Four credits. Prerequisites: LE/ESSE 2620 4.00 or LE/ENG 2120 4.00; LE/ESSE 3620 4.00 or LE/ENG 3120 4.00. Corequisite: LE/ESSE 3630 4.00 or LE/ENG 3130 4.00.  Prerequisites: LE/EATS 2620 4.00 or LE/ENG 2120 4.00; LE/EATS 3620 4.00 or LE/ENG 3120 4.00. Corequisite: LE/EATS 3630 4.00 or LE/ENG 3130 4.00. Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisites: SC/EATS 2620 4.00 or SC/ENG 2120 4.00; SC/EATS 3620 4.00 or SC/ENG 3120 4.00. Corequisite: SC/EATS 3630 4.00 or SC/ENG 3130 4.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Critical Reflection on Work Experience using Professional Portfolios
titletranslation: Critical Reflection on Work Experience using Professional Portfolios
description: Learning from the co-op experience and integrating that knowledge into academic studies. Use of the co-op e-Portfolio for targeted discussion topics focusing on professionalism, continuous learning, communications, and the workplace. Estimated time in required learning activities: three hours per week. Prerequisite: LE/COOP 2100 2.00. This course must be taken during the student's last co-op work-term. Enrolment in the Lassonde Co-op Option, requiring a GPA of 5.0 or better. Corequisites: LE/COOP 3109 0.00, or LE/COOP 4109 0.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Cooperative Education (COOP) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Atmospheric Radiation and Thermodynamics
description: Applications of basic thermodynamic principles to dry and moist atmospheric situations. Solar (short wave) and terrestrial (long wave) radiation with respect to absorption and scattering processes involving atmospheric atoms, molecules, aerosol particles and clouds. Prerequisites: SC/MATH 2015 3.00; SC/MATH 2271 3.00; SC/PHYS 1012 3.00; or SC/PHYS 1010 6.00; or any of the following acceptable substitutes: SC/PHYS 1801 3.00; or SC/ISCI 1310 6.00; or SC/ISCI 1302 3.00; or any of the following with a minimum grade of C in each course: SC/PHYS 1410 6.00; SC/PHYS 1420 6.00; SC/PHYS 1412 3.00; SC/PHYS 1422 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Understand the basic principles of thermal radiation
2. Understand the basic principles of atmospheric thermodynamics
3. Understand the interaction between radiative transfer, atmospheric thermal structure, convection, and clouds
4. Apply the principles of radiative transfer for remote sensing of atmospheric composition and temperature
5. Apply thermal radiation laws and meteorological parameters to develop simple models of climate
6. Apply thermal radiation laws and meteorological parameters to explain atmospheric composition and circulation in the troposphere and stratosphere
7. Apply meteorological data for predicting convection, cloud formation, and precipitation

title: Electrical Circuits
description: This course covers the basic principles of linear circuits. Kirchhoff's laws, circuit equations, RL, RC, and RLC circuits, three-phase circuits, power analysis and power factor, and magnetically coupled circuits. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit""5"), SC/PHYS 1010 6.00 or SC/PHYS 1801 3.00. Course credit exclusions: SC/PHYS 3050 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Analyze resistive circuits using basic laws (node and loop analysis, Thevenin, Norton's, superposition)
2. Determine the transient response of RC, RL, and RLC circuits
3. Analyze AC circuits in steady state using the phasor method
4. Use basic tools such as Matlab and SPICE for circuit analysis
5. Measure basic electrical signals using electronic measurement equipment in a lab setting.

description: Technological infrastructure for electronic commerce on the Internet. Terminology and architectures. Security and cryptography. Content presentation. Web protocols. title: Architecture and Hardware for Digital Signal Processing
titletranslation: Architecture and Hardware for Digital Signal Processing
description: This course introduces the students to the topics of special purpose architecture for Digital Signal Processing (DSP). It also addresses the methodologies needed to design custom or semi custom Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) circuits for DSP applications as well as the DSP support in general purpose processors. Twelve supervised lab hours. Prerequisites: General prerequisites; LE/CSE 3201 4.00; LE/CSE 3451 3.00. Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisites: General prerequisites; SC/CSE 3201 4.00; SC/CSE 3451 3.00.Prior to Fall 2009: Prerequisites: General prerequisites; AK/AS/SC/CSE 3201 4.00; AK/AS/SC/CSE 3451 3.00.

title: Digital Terrain Modeling
description: Digital Terrain Modeling concepts. Mathematical techniques in data acquisition, processing, storage, manipulation and applications. DTM. Surface representation using moving averages, linear projection and Kriging techniques. Grid resampling methods and search algorithms. DTM derivatives and applications. LIDAR systems and applications. Two lecture hours and three hours of laboratory exercises per week. One term. Three credits. Prerequisites: LE/EATS 2620 4.00 or LE/ENG 2110 2.00; LE/EATS 3620 4.00 or LE/ENG 3110 4.00. Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisites: SC/EATS 2620 4.00 or SC/ENG 2110 2.00; SC/EATS 3620 4.00 or SC/ENG 3110 4.00.

description: An introduction to robotic manipulators and autonomous vehicles. The course covers the kinematics and dynamics of manipulators and autonomous platforms, robot sensors and navigation. title: Cloud Physics and Radar Meteorology
description: Thermodynamics of cloud processes. Buoyancy and convection. Weather radar. Storms and associated precipitation. Cloud droplet formation and growth of ice crystals. Snow, graupel and hail. Microphysical processes and climate. Three lecture hours. One term. Three credits.  Prerequisite or corequisite: LE/EATS 3030 3.00.  Prior to Summer 2013: Prerequisite or corequisite: SC/EATS 3030 3.00.

title: Mobile User Interfaces
description: The design and implementation of user interfaces for touchscreen devices and tablet computers. Students develop user interfaces that include touch, multi-touch, vibration, device motion, position, and orientation, environment sensing, video capture, and audio capture. Twelve Supervised laboratory hours that emphasize these topics in a practical manner. Prerequisites: General prerequisite; LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 1030 3.00; LE/EECS 3461 3.00. (NOTE: The General Prerequisite is a cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses.  EECS courses with the second digit "5" are not major courses.)

title: Applied Electromagnetism
description: Provides the student with an introduction to the mathematics of electromagnetic wave propagation. This fundamental concept is expanded at length throughout the course by teaching specific applications such as electromagnetic propagation in free space, transmission lines, guided waves, and antennas. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); SC/MATH 1014 3.00 and SC/MATH 1025 3.00 and SC/PHYS 2020 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Comprehends the meaning of a partial differential equation (PDE) in a mathematical expression;
2. Analyzes transmission line problems, and comprehends how to apply these concepts to radio-frequency circuits;
3. Comprehends the meaning of the electromagnetic wave equation, and identifies its effects in free space and in waveguides;
4. Analyzes the operation of antennas.

title: Storms and Weather Systems
description: The study of mesoscale circulations and precipitating storm systems. Basic governing equations and instabilities. Nature and evolution of isolated convection, thunderstorms, mesoscale convective systems, precipitation bands, extratropical cyclones, fronts and frontogenesis, hurricanes, blizzards, polar lows and orographic storms. Prerequisites or corequisites: LE/ESSE 3040 3.00; LE/ESSE 4120 3.00. PRIOR TO FALL 2014: Prerequisites or corequisites: LE/EATS 3040 3.00; LE/EATS 4120 3.00. PRIOR TO SUMMER 2013: Prerequisites or corequisites: SC/EATS 3040 3.00; SC/EATS 4120 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Compilers and Interpreters
description: Principles and design techniques for compilers and interpreters. Compiler organization, compiler writing tools, scanning, parsing, semantic analysis, run-time storage organization, memory management, code generation and optimization. Students implement a substantial portion of a compiler in a project. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 1030 3.00; LE/EECS 2101 3.00 or LE/EECS 2011 3.00; LE/EECS 3301 3.00 is recommended.

title: Industry Practicum
description: This course is only available to students in the Industry Partnership Stream of the Computer Science Honours BSc (enrollment by permission). Students in the stream may enroll in the course during a term for which they are employed by the industrial partner. The learning outcomes of the course will be approved by the instructor prior to enrollment. Prerequisites: EECS credits in the 3000 level
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: The learning objectives of this course will vary depending on the nature of the student’s employment. The course instructor will establish the learning outcomes prior to student enrollment ensuring that they are appropriate for a 3 credit course at this level of study. Computer science learning outcomes must either closely match learning outcomes in existing EECS courses, or they must correspond to competencies in established international bodies like the ACM curriculum [1] or SWEBOK [2]. [1] http://www.acm.org/education/curricula-­‐recommendations [2] https://www.computer.org/web/swebok

The industry practicum courses will contribute to all degree level expectations listed above.  Each student will be a member of a particular team at the industry partner (e.g. security or mobile  development). The industry mentor will be tasked with enhancing the student’s depth and breadth of  knowledge on this topic. The student will become intimately familiar with the methodologies  employed by the industry partner, and will apply this knowledge on a real world situation. This  practical application will inform the student’s awareness of the limits of existing techniques.  Working on a real world project as part of a team will be beneficial for the student’s autonomy and  professional capacity. Finally, the student’s communication skills will be honed both through the  necessary communication with other team members, as well as the production of weekly reports that demonstrate the student’s progress.

title: Introduction to Physical Meteorology
description: An introduction to weather observation and prediction, atmospheric thermodynamics, thermodynamic charts, stability, clouds, fronts, air-masses, radiation, and climate. The course lectures are complemented by hands on laboratory and field experience. Prerequisite(s): LE/EECS 1541 3.00; MATH 1013 3.00 and MATH 1014 3.00, or equivalents; SC/PHYS 1012 3.00; or SC/PHYS 1010 6.00; or any of the following acceptable substitutes: SC/PHYS 1801 3.00; or SC/ISCI 1310 6.00; or SC/ISCI 1302 3.00; or any of the following with a minimum grade of C in each course: SC/PHYS 1410 6.00; SC/PHYS 1420 6.00; SC/PHYS 1412 3.00; SC/PHYS 1422 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1) Current and topical weather phenomena will be highlighted and analyzed in class.
2) Simple mathematical derivations of radiative and thermodynamic processes will be performed in lectures.
3) Opportunity for analysis based on meteorological tools including tephigrams and skew-T charts will be provided.
1) Recall cloud and weather system designations.
2) Explain the characteristics and evolution of various atmospheric phenomena.
3) Interpret thermodynamic variables and charts to describe atmospheric processes.
4) Evaluate the influence of clouds and radiation in atmospheric processes.
5) Use standard meteorological measurement techniques, tools, and observations.
