title: Landfill Design
description: A design-based course where geotechnical and hydrogeological principles are applied to study environmentally sustainable disposal of municipal solid waste. Students will conduct practical design tasks to investigate the planning, design, construction, operation and post-closure of phases of an engineered municipal waste disposal facility. Throughout their design tasks, topics studied will include: source and nature of waste; disposal options; design methodologies; environmental legislation and regulations; public perception; societal and environmental impact of landfills; contaminant transport modeling; use of geosynthetic materials; and design issues and tradeoffs. Prerequisites: CIVL 3210 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: To develop an understanding of modern municipal solid waste management practice and the role of landfilling in this context.

To recognize the wide range of technical and non‐technical considerations associated with site selection, approval, design, construction and operation of a modern waste management facility and understand the impact of the engineering solution in a global and societal context.
To develop an understanding of the sources and characteristics of municipal solid waste and the chemical and biological characteristics of landfill leachate.
To apply mathematical, scientific and engineering knowledge to the design of municipal solid waste landfill facility to meet specified needs and legislative requirements.

To understand the professional and ethical responsibility of an engineer with respect to waste management including consideration of social, economic, environmental, worker health and safety, and legislative and other regulatory issues.
To obtain experience working as a member of a design team and hence prepare for the engineering workplace.
1. Design a municipal solid waste landfill facility.
2. Describe solid waste bio‐degradation and characteristics of landfill leachate
3. Understand and explain the strengths and limitations of different liner systems
4. Estimate contaminating life span of the landfill based on size, infiltration and peak leachate characteristics
5. Consider and address public perception and environmental impact issues in landfill design
6. Explain the importance of standards and regulations within the context of landfill design, management and closures.

title: Geological Processes
description: This course presents essential topics in physical geology and earth sciences, including: plate tectonics and the geological cycle; identification and physical properties of rocks, soil and minerals; igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rock formation; weathering and soil formation; structural geology and geological mapping; relative age relationships; and, near-surface geological processes and resulting landforms. The course also briefly introduces the students to the topics of earthquakes, landslides and other natural hazards and develops links to the physical properties. Prerequisite: ESSE 1012 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Civil Engineering (CIVL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: The course aims to provide the students with essential concepts in physical geology and earth science so as to enable them to apply these concepts in upper-year geotechnical, geological, and geoenvironmental courses in the Civil Engineering undergraduate curriculum. title: Freight Transportation
description: CIVL 4034 Freight Transportation builds on core transportation courses by adapting the concepts and theories of passenger transportation to the realm of freight transportation with an emphasis on truck patterns. This topic is regionally important given the prominent role of nearby Peel Region as the largest Canadian hub for freight. The course will cover topics such as traditional freight modelling assumptions, the demand for goods movement arising from economic markets, trip generation models, truck movement models such as truck tours, societal impacts of freight, and future impacts of connected and autonomous (CAV) vehicles. In addition, the course will introduce students to optimization problems such as the transportation problem, p-median, and capacitated plant. Prerequisites: LE/CIVL 3250 3.00 or LE/CIVL 3260 3.00

title: Power System Analysis
description: This course provides the theoretical and practical knowledge to analyze electric power grids and design the respective elements. The content of this course has wide applications in different areas of power system engineering, including power system operation, control, protection, and stability. These topics include a review of admittance and impedance models of power systems, power flow analysis, symmetrical faults, symmetrical components and sequence networks, asymmetrical faults, transients of transmission lines, state estimation in power systems, and transient stability. The lab component of this course trains the student to use simulation programs for validating the theoretical content of the course. Prerequisites: LE/EECS 3622 4.00 or LE/EECS 4622 4.00. Co-requisites: LE/EECS 3603 4.00

title: Dynamics of Space Vehicles
description: This course presents a coherent and unified framework for mathematical modeling and analysis of space vehicles. The course can be divided into two main parts: orbit dynamics and attitude dynamics and control. The topics covered by this course include two-body problem, coordinate transformation, orbital elements, perturbation theory, orbital maneuvers, relative motion and rendezvous, interplanetary trajectories, rocket dynamics, and attitude dynamics and control. Spacecraft dynamics and control problems of practical interests are treated from a dynamical systems point of view. This course will focus on a comprehensive treatment of spacecraft dynamics and control problems and their practical solutions. Prerequisites: SC/PHYS 2010 3.00 or LE/ESSE 2470 3.00; SC/MATH 2271 3.00. Course Credit exclusion: SC/PHYS 4110 3.00

title: Introduction to Computer Science and Programming
titletranslation: Introduction to Computer Science and Programming
description:
This course is an introduction to the concepts and tools of computer science as students learn a procedural subset of the Python programming language. Python has a variety of libraries in different domains allowing for the solution of interesting problems which has made it a popular language in industry and the academy. Students do hands-on work to design, write, debug and test computer programs that solve problems computationally.

Students study variables, assignments, expressions (arithmetic, relational and logical) and sequencing of statements to implement solutions for computational problems, in Python. They document programs with comments and preconditions. They analyze the type correctness of programs via a type checker. They use an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) to develop, unit-test and debug programs given a problem specification. They apply conditionals (including nested conditionals) to implement algorithms to solve computational problems. They code functions to develop modular programming solutions for computational problems. They apply Python loops (including nested loops) to implement algorithms to solve computational problems. They apply data structures, including tuples, sets, lists and dictionaries, to implement algorithms to solve computational
problems. They code simple recursive functions to implement algorithms to solve computational problems. Prerequisites: One of (1)-(3) below must be met: (1) (New high school curriculum): One 4U Math course with a grade of at least 75%. (2) Completion of six credits from York University MATH courses (not including courses with second digit 5) with a GPA of 5.00 or better over these credits; (3) Completion of six credits from York University mathematics courses whose second digit is 5, with an average grade not below 7.00 (B+).
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Introduction to Climate Science
description: This course surveys key physical and dynamical processes responsible for maintaining Earth's climate. Components of the climate system. Energy balance of the climate system, radiative processes, the hydrological cycle, the general circulations in the atmosphere and ocean. The roles of these processes in setting both global-mean and regional climate under both annual-mean and seasonal-mean conditions is discussed extensively. The relevance of these processes for recent climate change is also discussed. Prerequisites: LE/ESSE 1011 3.00 or LE/ESSE 1012 3.00 or EU/GEOG 1401 3.00 or EU/GEOG 1400 6.00; SC/MATH 1013 3.00 and SC/MATH 1014 3.00, or equivalents; LE/EECS 1011 3.00 or LE/EECS 1520 3.00 or LE/EECS 1540 3.00 or LE/EECS 1541 3.00; SC/PHYS 1010 6.00 or SC/PHYS 1012 3.00 or SC/PHYS 1801 3.00 or SC/ISCI 1302 3.00 or SC/ISCI 1310 6.00 or any of the following with a minimum grade of C in each course: SC/PHYS 1410 6.00 or SC/PHYS 1420 6.00 or SC/PHYS 1412 3.00 or SC/PHYS 1422 3.00

title: Object-Oriented Problem Solving
description: DIGT1201 introduces students to the fundamentals of object-oriented programming and problem-solving skills. Students will gain knowledge and computational skills related to designing object-oriented solutions, using APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), inheritance, composition, event-driven programming, and recursion. They will also learn about professional software development processes such as test-driven development, debugging, software versioning, documentation, and agile methodologies. title: Data Structures, Algorithms & Analysis
description:
DIGT 2102 introduces fundamental data structures and algorithms as well as asymptotic algorithm analysis. Topics include arrays, linked lists, hash tables, queues, search trees, sorting algorithms, graph data structures, elementary graph algorithms (traversal, shortest path, topological sort), and algorithm design techniques such as greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, and stochastic algorithms.

The course spans three terms (F, W, S). The course starts with simple data structures and introduces increasingly complex data structures while gradually delving into algorithmic design. The course is organized into three distinct terms, each adding more complexity both on data structures and algorithms. Throughout each term, students will design and implement one or two software applications that require the use of fundamental data structures and search algorithms.  Students will develop their communication skills and enhance their e-portfolio. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 1201 8.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 2102 4.00, LE/CSSD 2202 4.00, LE/EECS 2101 3.00, LE/EECS 3101 3.00.

title: Security Fundamentals
description:
DIGT2302 provides a first introduction on cybersecurity exploring security and digital safety concerns both from a user’s and from a system administrator’s perspective. It presents a holistic systems security approach covering human, organizational, and environmental aspects. Students will look at common security vulnerabilities included in comprehensive and longitudinal classifications such as OWASP and CWE. They will learn how to recognize, detect, prevent, and patch these vulnerabilities, as well as to create threat models for them. They will also use fundamental testing and detection tools, including Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) Tools. They will explore basic notions of personal and system security including access control, authentication, and identity management. Finally, students will review digital investigation methods as part of the software development lifecycle and software quality assurance and discuss the limitations of digital forensics.

Throughout the term, students will practice these concepts in small independent practical assignments individually or in small groups, where they will study small systems that have been intentionally developed with security vulnerabilities for training purposes. Students will analyze these systems for security vulnerabilities, provide reports and evaluations on their security and fix them by applying the appropriate mitigation techniques and patches. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT2103 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3482 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

description: This course is focused on teamwork and communication in developing software projects. Topics include communication within centralized, decentralized, and global software teams, collaborative software development, version control systems, issue repositories, open-sourced, crowdsourced, and outsourced software, knowledge sharing and Q/A platforms, ethics, individual and team productivity, diversity, and inclusion within teams. Course credit exclusions: LE/DIGT 1161 2.00

title: Design of Human-Made Structures
description: How are infrastructure systems designed? From the electricity grid to water/wastewater systems to transportation infrastructure, this course explores the design of and human-built systems that support society. These systems will be analyzed through a lens of sustainability and the UN SDGs. This course is designed for a general audience who is curious about the wonders of engineering.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Technology at Lassonde (TECL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Reading - Students will develop and apply scientific literacy by reading texts outside the field of their major that will include technical scientific and engineering information.

Writing - Students will write a multi-page report that will consider multiple perspectives, compare technologies, and use evidence to justify a claim. Students will be guided on how to write in the genre, how to judge the trustworthiness of sources, and how to properly cite courses using APA style.
Speaking and Listening - Students will be expected to engage in tutorial discussions, listening and responding to their peers.

Critical Thinking - The comparative report will involve identifying the strengths and weaknesses of a set of infrastructure technologies, and students will need to recommend a specific technology to be used in a given context. To do so, students will need to define criteria for comparing technologies (e.g. impact on society, sustainability, cost), balance tradeoffs, and use evidence to justify their recommendation. This will need to consider multiple views (e.g. community needs, environment, industry) which may conflict with each other.
Research Skills - Students will be introduced to library resources (including scientific databases), given guidance on how to trust the information in a source.
Explain the design of the constructed world that they encounter in everyday life.
Describe how the design of infrastructure can facilitate or impede sustainable development.
Give constructive feedback to peers in a professional manner.
Write a comparative report that critically evaluates infrastructure technologies.

title: Logic and Computing
description: CSSD1203 introduces the mathematical foundations needed for computer science. Topics include elementary propositional and predicate logic, techniques for proving statements, and asymptotic notation, binary representation, and modular arithmetic. The emphasis is on developing the understanding of fundamental properties of programs, that concerns both their running time and correctness. Prerequisites: SC/MATH 1516 3.00; LE/CSSD 1050 3.00 or LE/CSSD 1101 3.00 or CSSD1102 3.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 1019 3.00, LE/EECS 1028 3.00, SC/MATH 1019 3.00, SC/MATH 1028 3.00, SC/MATH 2320 3.00.

title: Software Design
description: CSSD2203 covers fundamental software engineering principles and development of skills for the design and implementation of software systems. Topics include basic principles of software development processes with emphasis on agile methods and test-driven development, and UML-based software design specification. The course introduces foundational software engineering principles related to the design of software systems, in-depth analysis of software systems architecture and design patterns, design of APIs, antipattern detection strategies, refactoring, principles of distributed software architectures, metrics and standards for assessing software design quality assurance practices and communicating design decisions through software design models. Pre-requisites: LE/CSSD 2101 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3311 3.00, LE/DIGT 3141 3.00.

title: Legal Values: Commercializing IP
description:
Navigating legal issues is crucial to the commercialization of new technologies. This course will examine the application of substantive intellectual property (IP) law in the context of IP management for in-house lawyers or IP managers within IP-rich organizations. Through case studies and facilitated discussion, students will apply principles central to IP management, including creation, development, protection, and exploitation of intellectual property rights as a business asset. Guest speakers will supplement the course’s examination of key technology specific issues relating to high technology and sciences.
In particular, this course will examine the process of creating, capturing, protecting, leveraging and transferring technology and ideas, including internal strategies designed to create a culture of innovation; deciding whether, what, where, and how to obtain IP registrations and the related economics; the development of a commercialization strategy (such as selecting the target market and application for the idea) and business model; drafting and negotiating related agreements; offensive and defensive IP strategies; assessing competitive IP; negotiating and interpreting IP sensitive contracts; and transactional IP processes.
Course Credit Exclusion: LW-LAW 3591M 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Technology at Lassonde (TECL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Data Structures & Algorithms

Throughout the term, students develop several problem-solving projects focusing on fundamental data structures including search and graph-related data structures and algorithms.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning II
description: DIGT3231 is the second course of the Introduction to Machine Learning series (DIGT 3131 and DIGT 3231). DIGT3131 and DIGT 3231 together present an introduction to machine learning. DIGT 3231 covers more advanced mathematical concepts, and techniques such as neural networks, unsupervised learning, model evaluation, and feature selection. Students will learn to implement and evaluate various machine learning algorithms using Python and libraries like Scikit-learn, applying these algorithms to real-world datasets. title: Object-Oriented Programming
description:
CSSD2101 continues the separation of concern theme introduced in its predecessor CSSD1201. This  course focuses on the concern of the implementer. Hence, rather than using an API (Application Programming Interface) to build an application the student is asked to implement a given API specification. Topics include implementing classes (delegation within the class definition, documentation and API generation, and implementing contracts), aggregations (implementing aggregates versus compositions and implementing collections), inheritance hierarchies (attribute  visibility, overriding methods, abstract classes, inner classes); generics; examples of event-driven programming; recursion; basic searching and sorting algorithms as OO applications). Examples of  lists; stacks and queues using an OO paradigm. The coverage also includes an introduction to UML  class diagrams and a few basic OO design patterns.

Throughout the term, students develop incrementally in small groups an object-aware software  project using a simplified software development process of at least four phases, professional development technologies such as IDEs (Integrated Development Environment), and testing frameworks. The course promotes self-directed learning, coding by design, design by contract,  principle of layering, pair-programming or teamwork, and enhancing ePortfolio.  Pre-requites: LE/CSSD 1201 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/DIGT 1201 8.00, LE/EECS 2030 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Computer Science for Software Development (CSSD) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Mobile GIS and Location-based Services
description:
In the past decades, emerging technologies such as the internet, distributed computing, positioning, data mining and augmented reality have caused a paradigm shift to spatial computations and decisions from local-scale, off-line and static system to large-scale, on-line and mobile one. Most of our everyday decisions are closely related to the space we occupy. This rapid advancement of spatial information technology allows us to make timely and accurate spatial decisions. 
This course explores the development of modern web-based architectures of GIS applications which support the spatial decision process over the internet. The course provides a broad introduction to web application architectures, geo-open sources, geo-metadata, OGC standards, 3D spatial data, spatial database interaction and indoor positioning. Using geo-open sources and pre-designed elements (plug-ins, mashups and service scripts), the students will learn how to build a web-based mapping service by themselves through lab assignments and individual term projects. Built on the fundamental principles of GIS introduced in ESSE 3600 (GIS and Spatial Analysis) this course draws from numerous case studies and applications enabling the students to learn how to apply spatial analysis and decision algorithms for implementing a range of web-based and location-based services from health, facility and disaster management to consumer applications.  Two lecture hours and three laboratory hours per week. Prerequisites: LE/EECS 1021 3.00, LE/ESSE 3600 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Introduction to Energy Systems
description: Introduction to basic modeling and analysis techniques in electricity generation, transmission and distribution. Introduction to 3-phase systems, single line diagrams and Per Unit system of calculations. Functional descriptions and modeling of generators, transformers, transmission lines, motors and other loads are discussed. title: Introduction to Sensors and Measurement Instruments
titletranslation: Introduction to Sensors and Measurement Instruments
description: Covers the theory, principle and technology of sensors and measurement concepts by developing the students' understanding of fundamental of measurement instruments encompassing sensors and interfacing techniques to transfer the measured data for monitoring and/or further signal processing purposes. There will be small design projects for the labs to reinforce sensor interfacing. Topics include the fundamental of physical, chemical, and biological sensors used for various applications including health or industrial applications; design of interface circuit dedicated to each sensor; quality factors of sensors' performance including resolution, dynamic range and sensitivity. Also this course enables the electrical engineering students to learn the principle and operation of main electrical measurement instruments. The state of art sensor technology and the job opportunities in this field will also be discussed briefly. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"), LE/EECS 2210 3.00, background in electronic circuit design, basic knowledge of physics, chemistry and molecular/cellular biology.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: The primary objective will be on developing the student's ability to integrate and apply their knowledge in electronic circuits and classic knowledge in physical, chemical and  biological science in the design of measurements using advanced sensing technologies. Specifically, students will:
Investigate measurement sensing techniques used for various applications.
Use electrical instruement of voltage, current, power and energy.
Design interface circuits and systems to record sensing data into a computer for monitoring and simple signal processing purposes.
Analyze  the  measurement  question  and  select  an  appropriate the sensor technology and interfacing method to develop the instrument.
Describe the state of are sensing technology and the market challenges in this field.

title: Cadastral Studies
description:
Land and interests in land including how rights to land are owned, tenure and estates and lesser interests and how rights to land are transferred. The Canadian Legal System, including case law and precedent; common law; Civil Law in Quebec; principles of evidence; Expert and lay witnesses; Estoppel; Constitution Act; Limitation of actions; Easements and rights of ways; Statutory rights of way (or rights of way without a dominant tenement): Exceptions and reservations; Covenants, Adverse possession; Dedication of roads; Expropriation; Escheat, The link between the land surveyor and the law of real property. Concepts of boundaries including the nature of a boundary, creation and elimination of boundaries and the movement of boundaries. Subdivisions and consolidations. Bornage in Quebec. Retracement and reestablishment of lost or obliterated boundaries; Resolution of boundary uncertainty; Hierarchy of evidence; Jurisdictional boundaries. Prerequisites: LE/ESSE 2620 3.00
Date of submission: February 6, 2018
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Earth, Space Science and Engineering (ESSE) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
description:
Introduction to abstraction. Use and development of precise formulations of mathematical ideas. Informal introduction to logic; introduction to naïve set theory; induction; relations and functions; big O-notation; recursive definitions, recurrence relations and their solutions; graphs and trees. Three lecture hours per week. Plus, drop-in optional problem sessions as well as instructor office hours, as these are announced in each term. 

Prerequisites: SC/MATH 1190 3.00 or SC/MATH 1200 3.00 or SC/MATH 2200 3.00, or two 4U Math courses, including MHF4U (Advanced Function).
Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 1028 3.00, SC/MATH 1028 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Apply logical arguments, definitions, set identities, and mathematical induction to write valid proofs using a variety of methods;
2. Compare functions in terms of their structure and growth by proving properties of given functions (e.g. one-to-one, onto, big-O, big-Omega, big-Theta, infinity);
3. Prove properties of recursively defined structures and solve counting problems and recurrence relations; and
4. Analyze graphs to determine the properties they have (e.g. type of graph, connectivity, Euler and Hamilton paths and circuits, trees)

title: Power Electronics
description: The objective of this course is to understand the basic operating principles of power conversion using advanced electronic devices. The structure and characteristics of several switching devices are reviewed. Basic power electronic converters and inverters such as AC/DC rectifiers, DC/DC switch mode converters and voltage source DC/AC inverters are studied. Resonant DC/DC converters are introduced. Computation of circuit quantities such as average and RMS value, average power, power factor, total harmonics distortion and power efficiency are also studied. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"), LE/EECS 2210 3.00. Corequisite: LE/EECS 3603 4.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

4.  Demonstrate the ability to mathematically compute switching losses, conduction  losses, and power efficiency
5. Demonstrate the ability to determine the suitable control method for the  corresponding converter or inverter.
6.     Derive mathematical equations that characterize the voltage gain of basic DC/DC converters.
7.   Demonstrate the ability to draw steady-state operating waveforms of  AC/DC rectifiers, DC/DC converters, DC/AC inverters
8.     Understand the features and drawbacks of different isolated DC/DC converters
9.     Understand the basic operating principles of resonant power conversion.
10.  Demonstrate the ability to design simple power electronic circuits for real-life applications
1)    Understand the different types of power sion that takes place in power electronics

title: Net-Centric Computing
description: Net-centric computing encompasses numerous technologies but is based on a three underlying principles: Client-Server Computing, Content Management, and Browser-Based Applications. This course covers these principles in general and examines a representative subset of the prevailing technologies. Topics include network programming; web applications; database connectivity; content representation and presentation; and client-side programming. Three weekly lecture hours and three lab hours every other week. One term.  Four credits. Prerequisites: General prerequisites. Course credit exclusions: AP/ITEC 3020 3.00; SC/CSE 2041 3.00, SC/CSE 2041 4.00.

outcomes.value: 1. Describe software specifications via Design by Contract, including the use of preconditions, postconditions, class invariants, loop variants and invariants
2. Implement specifications with designs that are correct, efficient and maintainable.
3. Develop systematic approaches to organizing, writing, testing and debugging software.
4.  Develop insight into the process of moving from an ambiguous problem statement to a well-­‐ designed solution (analysis).
5. Design software using appropriate abstractions, information hiding, and design patterns  (design).

6. Develop facility in the use of an IDE for editing, organizing, writing, debugging, testing and  documenting code including the use of BON/UML diagrams for documenting designs. Also the ability  to deploy the software in an executable form.
7. Develop the ability to write precise and concise software documentation that also describes the design decisions and why they were made.

outcomes.value: Establish the solid foundation of analytical approaches of error analysis.
Understand the fundamentals and master the methods/procedures of hypothesis testing of direct measurements.
Build up the essential basis for further data analysis and parameter estimation.
Understand the fundamentals of least square principles
Master the methods for least squares fitting and regression of linear and non-linear functions.
Solve problems using least squares estimation.
Identify the statistics to describe measurements and errors.
Apply the various test statistics to practical problems.
Demonstrate the understanding of concepts of error propagation and apply it to practical problems.
Apply the fundamental concepts to conduct least-square estimation.
Solve linear and nonlinear fitting problem using least squares.

title: Signals and Systems in Continuous Time
titletranslation: Signals and Systems in Continuous Time
description:
Introduces continuous-time (analogue) signals including an analysis and design of continuous-time systems. After reviewing core concepts in complex numbers, trigonometry, and functions, the course considers three alternate representations (differential equations, impulse response, and Laplace/Fourier transfer function) for linear, time invariant (LTI) systems in the continuous-time domain. The analysis of LTI systems is covered for each of the three representations. Frequency-selective filters are introduced as a special class of LTI systems for which design techniques based on Butterworth, Chebyshev, and Elliptic filters are covered. Applications of continuous-time systems in communications and controls are also presented.

title: Environmental Impact Assessment and Sustainability
description: The course introduces the process of environmental impact assessment (EIA) in the context of sustainable development in Canada. The role of the EIA process in engineering design and control of adverse environmental effects is illustrated using a number of case studies. Regulations such as Clean Water Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, Environmental Assessment Act, and Environmental Protection Act will be discussed. Prerequisites: LE/CIVL 2240 3.00, LE/CIVL 3210 3.00

title: Introduction to Power Systems
description: The course discusses the basic modeling and analysis techniques in electrical energy systems including generation, transmission, and distribution systems. It covers the power system fundamentals consisting of 3-phase systems, complex and phasor quantities, single line diagrams and Per Unit system of calculations. Concept of complex power and active and reactive power are covered and reactive power compensation is also described. Functional descriptions and modeling of generators, transformers, transmission lines, motors and other loads are discussed. Various types of renewable energy systems are also introduced and basic functionality of the critical components of these systems are discussed. Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better over all major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 2200 3.00. Course Credit Exclusion LE/EECS 4622 4.00

title: Introduction to Medical Devices and Biological Instruments
titletranslation: Introduction to Medical Devices and Biological Instruments
description: This course builds on the foundation in measurement techniques by developing the students' understanding of electrophysiological sensing systems and biosensors used within the medical and biological fields. This course applies the classical knowledge of electronic circuits and systems techniques to the development of medical devices and biological instruments. Background in electronic circuit design, basic knowledge of human physiology and body system, and basic knowledge of cellular and molecular biology are required before taking the course. Topics include the design of medical devices such as Electro-Encephalography (EEG) and Electromyography (EMG) devices used for disease diagnostics; biological instruments such as cell counter; handheld sensing devices used for various point-of-care (PoC) applications such as glucose measurement, blood pressure monitoring and early detection of cancer; and wearable sensing devices used for fitness applications. In the design of each medical device or biological instrument, students are also introduced the related theoretical and practical issues with a focus on needs assessment, creativity, and innovation as they seek to identify market opportunities. Prerequisites: cumulative GPA of 4.50 or better overall major EECS courses (without second digit "5"); LE/EECS 1021 3.00, LE/EECS 2210 3.00. Course Credit Exclusion: LE/EECS 4641 4.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Coding through Biology (CS1 A)
description: Introduction to fundamentals of procedural programming in the context of biology. The lecture component is in two parts: some lectures focus on computer programming skills, and other lectures focus on selected topics from biology. The laboratory component allows students to strengthen computing skills and understanding of the biological concepts through computer simulations and problem solving. Through this experiential journey, students will learn the fundamentals of programming, computational problem solving, as well as the software development process. This course typically runs from week 1 to week 6 of the term. CSSD1101 and CSSD1102 both cover fundamental programming concepts and are meant to reinforce each other by covering those concepts in two different contexts. title: Object Oriented Design and Principles using Python
titletranslation: Object Oriented Design and Principles using Python
description: This course introduces the core concepts of object-oriented programming aiming at data science students with no prior experience of object-oriented design and programming. It focuses on subjects such as classes, objects, encapsulation, abstraction, inheritance, polymorphism, and the practical application of object-oriented design that is most useful in the domain of data science. These topics include data structures such as Stacks, Queues, linked data structures and trees.  Data Science professionals require to work with algorithms that run in a reasonable time on large data sets. For this, computational complexity as a tool to evaluate the efficiency of designed algorithms is introduced. The language of choice is Python. Prerequisite: LE/EECS 1015 3.00.

title: Special Topics - Commercializing Intellectual Property
description:
Navigating legal issues is crucial to the commercialization of new technologies. This course will examine the application of substantive intellectual property (IP) law in the context of IP management for in-house lawyers or IP managers within IP-rich organizations. Through case studies and facilitated discussion, students will apply principles central to IP management, including creation, development, protection, and exploitation of intellectual property rights as a business asset. Guest speakers will supplement the course’s examination of key technology specific issues relating to high technology and sciences.
In particular, this course will examine the process of creating, capturing, protecting, leveraging and transferring technology and ideas, including internal strategies designed to create a culture of innovation; deciding whether, what, where, and how to obtain IP registrations and the related economics; the development of a commercialization strategy (such as selecting the target market and application for the idea) and business model; drafting and negotiating related agreements; offensive and defensive IP strategies; assessing competitive IP; negotiating and interpreting IP sensitive contracts; and transactional IP processes.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Technology at Lassonde (TECL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1.	Understand the challenges and opportunities for developing and commercializing intellectual property (IP), including the purposes for developing IP and different ways in which IP can be monetized.
2.	Review case studies of innovative companies to assess IP commercialization strategies.
3.	Refine your critical analytical skills to be able to communicate your views orally through in class contributions and in your writing.
4.	Prepare a memorandum with detailed analysis for a major case study.

title: Technological Countermeasures to Financial Crimes
description:
Financial technology is an emerging industry that aims to replace or enhance traditional financial services with technological solutions. While financial technology aims to make financial services more
accessible to the general public, it is also a crucial component in the fight against financial crimes. The rapid advancement of technology and digital transformation has contributed to the growth and
complexity of financial crimes. This course provides an overview of financial crimes and examines key technologies used to combat them. 
• Students gain a broad view of financial crimes including history, definitions, methodologies, financial intelligence units, regulations, and financial crime investigation. Various concepts such as Know Your Customer, Customer Due Diligence, Anti-Money Laundering, Combating the Financing of Terrorism, regulatory reporting, and risk assessment will be covered. 
• Students study current and emerging key technologies employed to identify and combat financial crimes such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, natural language processing, big data analytics, distributed ledgers, virtual currency, and privacy enhancing technologies.
• Students apply the technologies to solve real-world problems via case studies and projects. 
• Students benefit from many experiential education opportunities via guest lecturers from industry, and case studies and projects suggested and mentored by volunteer professionals currently working in the field.

This course is suitable for students who intend to pursue a career in banking, accounting, finance, financial technology, anti-money laundering, fraud management, corporate security, law enforcement,
compliance, policy making, and cyber-security. Prerequisites: Cumulative grade point average of 4.5 or higher over all major EECS courses; LE/EECS 2101 3.00 or LE/EECS 2011 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

apply AI, machine learning, and big data analytics techniques to CDD, KYC, Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) and Suspicious Transaction Report (STR) processes, and ML/TF transaction monitoring.
gain an understanding of privacy enhancing technologies, blockchain technology and virtual currencies.
identify and describe different types of financial crimes;

identify and analyze a financial crime risk; propose technological solutions to mitigate the risk.

title: Technology Leadership & Professional Reflection 1
description:
This course introduces foundational concepts and practices of leadership and reflection. It develops students’ skills needed to succeed and thrive in technology-oriented programs and in technology and computing related fields.  Students will develop cognitive, emotional, and relational foundations for learning, thriving, leadership, and contribution with emphasis on learning from students’ professional and academic experience through reflection frameworks.

This course is the first of four courses in a course series (1.0 credit each).

title: Web Development Basics
description: DIGT1302 covers technologies and skills for web and mobile programming, with a major focus on client-side development, and a smaller focus on server-side implementation. Topics include an introduction to network/Internet protocols; principles of layering, coding by design, and design by contract, particularly applied to web and mobile application architectures; event-driven programming, user interface design, layouts, and dynamic content; server-side model design; client- and server-side scripting; and interacting with data sources. Students will be informed to maintain a security mindset in their development process. In this journey, students will survey knowledge related to responsive design of full stack web and mobile application development and will learn at least one set of technologies more deeply to develop an industry- or community- inspired web/mobile project while improving skills in software versioning, debugging, and teamwork. The lectures are supplemented by practical programming tasks closely integrated with workplace activities. The project is developed using a simplified software development process with multiple stages, e.g., documentation/design/development/demonstration. The course promotes self-directed learning, coding by design, design by contract, the principle of layering, pair-programming or teamwork, the use of APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), and enhancing students’ e-portfolios.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

title: Introduction to Neuromorphic Computing: From Principles to Hardware Design
titletranslation: Introduction au calcul neuromorphique : Des principes à la conception matérielle
description: This course introduces neuromorphic computing's basic principles for both algorithms and implementations in digital hardware.  It discusses the motivation for neuromorphic computing, neuroscience principles and their connection with electronics and computer engineering.  Topics include spiking neural networks (SNNs), spiking neuron models, hardware implementations of neuronal circuits, synaptic models, synaptic hardware implementations, inter-neuron communications, network realizations, neural coding schemes, learning algorithms (conversion from artificial neural networks to SNNs, supervised and unsupervised training algorithms), usage of memory for neuromorphic systems, emerging memory technologies for SNNs, faults in neuromorphic systems, fault-tolerant neuromorphic system design, a review of state of the art neuromorphic computing hardware, and the design of reconfigurable neuromorphic systems. Course Prerequisite: LE/EECS 2200 3.00, LE/EECS 3201 4.00, LE/EECS 3404 3.00 or LE/EECS 3405 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

Design, implement and test a real neuromorphic system

Design, implement, and test a neuromorphic computing system for a new real-world problem (GAI 4.3)

title: Being a Digital Citizen
description:
In this course, students are critically introduced to the digital world they inhabit. Students identify, discuss, and apply concepts of digital ethics to questions and the search for answers in the digital world, with a focus on communicating the development and effects these tools and technologies have on our lives.

Driving this course is the question: “What do we need to know and do in relation to the past and present of digital technologies to be active, ethical, and literate digital citizens?”
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Students will be introduced to histories of and cultures within the digital world.
Students will be invited to explore the controversies and problems associated with the rise of the digital.
Students will engage in discovering the possibilities of the digital for ethical creativity and growth.
Students will be introduced to and engage in research and presentation strategies that are ethical and take copyright and access into consideration.
Students will understand both the personal and social implications of pressing ethical issues related to the digital world.

Students will identify and explain the significance of historical, political, economic, and/or socio-cultural trends and issues related to the contemporary use of digital tools, information sources, and technologies

Students will create and reflect on a research question related to the digital world, and identify and articulate research strategies that critically and ethically assesses different sources of information
Students will explore and reflect on ethical issues facing digital citizens, and identify and communicate salient issues for themselves and others
Students will critically analyze and develop a response related to online content, recognizing how resources differ based on authorship, research methodology, and information purpose
Students will identify possibilities and potential for creative, ethical, and interdisciplinary exploration in digital worlds

Students will define, develop, and demonstrate a sense of personal academic integrity, recognizing the significance and implications of being academically honest in and out of school, along with the obligations we all hold to others’ dignity and privacy in online spaces or when creating media

title: Principles of Operating Systems
description: Modern computer systems consist of layers of hardware and software that interact to present a particular machine abstraction. This course focuses on the operating system and other pieces of software that build the layers of abstraction that hide the hardware details and system complexities from programs and programmers. This layering of abstractions simplifies programming and allows programmers to reason about and build complex systems. Understanding their implementation allows users to evaluate the system's behaviour and improve its performance. In particular, the relationships and interactions between the various layers of abstraction can have profound effects on the performance, security, and correctness of services and capabilities provided by these abstractions. Prerequisites: LE/DIGT 2103 4.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/EECS 3221 3.00, LE/CSSD 3107 2.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Students will learn how abstractions used by modern operating systems provide processes with an illusion of an isolated system in a shared environment.
Students will learn how operating system kernels use limited direct execution to share CPU execution times across multiple untrusted processes.
Students will learn how virtual memory is used to provide a shared and efficient use of memory resources.
Students will learn how processes use system calls to get access to restricted hardware resources.
Students will learn how to create simple concurrent programs using threads.
Students will learn how to use synchronization mechanisms to avoid race conditions, deadlocks and other related issues in concurrent programs.
Students will learn how file systems are implemented in modern operating systems.
Students will learn how authentication and access control are implemented in modern operating systems.
Students will learn how hypervisors (virtual machine managers) provide guest operating systems access to a virtual view of physical hardware resources.

CLO1: Explain the mechanisms and policies used by modern operating systems to share a computer’s hardware resources among multiple untrusted and competing processes using limited direct execution, process scheduling and virtual memory.
CLO2: Design programs that make effective use of system calls and other operating system interfaces.
CLO3: Design and implement efficient concurrent programs using threads that are free of race conditions, deadlocks, livelocks and starvation issues.
CLO4: Identify strategies and trade-offs for the implementation of file systems that account for performance, security, and resiliency.
CLO5: Explain appropriate mechanisms used by operating systems to provide and limit access to system resources based on configurable privileges.
CLO6: Identify modern implementations of virtual machines, including the role of type 1 and type 2 hypervisors, as well as common implementations of virtual CPUs, memory, and disks.

title: Fundamentals of Machine Learning
description: This course introduces fundamental machine learning concepts and techniques in a rigorous way to illustrate how basic machine learning methods are constructed from the underlying motivations and mathematical principles. It also explores in depth how to formulate machine learning problems and how to implement basic machine learning systems to solve various problems from diverse real-world application domain. The course emphasizes the mathematical foundations of machine learning as well as practical experience in implementing machine learning algorithms. Pre-requisites: LE/EECS 2030 3.00 or LE/EECS 2031 3.00 or LE/EECS 2032 4.00 or LE/EECS 1516 3.00; SC/MATH 2030 3.00 or SC/MATH 2930 3.00 or SC/MATH 1131 3.00; SC/MATH 1025 3.00 or SC/MATH 1021;  SC/MATH 2015 3.00 or SC/MATH 2310 3.00. Course Credit Exclusions: LE/EECS 3404 3.00, LE/EECS 4404 3.00, LE/DIGT 3131 3.00, LE/DIGT 3231 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Explain how data can be used to train machine learning systems

Design and implement basic machine learning algorithms and apply them to practical problems utilizing best practices

Formulate problems for the use of machine learning such that appropriate machine learning algorithms can be applied
Use standard numerical and data processing software libraries to implement basic machine learning methods

title: Introduction à l’informatique et à la programmation
description: Il s’agit d’un cours d'introduction à l’informatique et aux langages de programmation. Le cours est conçu pour former les étudiants à l’utilisation des plates-formes R et Python pour résoudre les problèmes de calcul qui se posent dans les sciences.

title: Innovation, Creativity and Entrepreneurship
description:
Being creative is about solving problems or approaching opportunities in novel and valuable ways. This course, is designed to help students harness their creative potential by stimulating their own creative process, in order to help them develop ideas that create real value and have a positive impact on society.
Creativity can be applied across many disciplines, and this course is designed for students from all faculties, with enhanced learning opportunities fostered through projects delivered in cross disciplinary teams.
The course will help students learn how to observe and frame critical problems, and then identify and choose potential solutions that can be implemented by individuals or organizations. As a consequence of participating in this course, students will become an innovation enabler in any type of organization, or better able to use their own creativity to create a startup.
Students will start by exploring their own creativity and problem solving style, before being introduced to creative problems solving frameworks, tools and processes, which they can deploy while solving real problems, both individually and in teams. Course credit exclusions: LE/ENG 1101 4.00, LE/ENG 1102 4.00, AP/ENTP 2920 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Technology at Lassonde (TECL) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: 1. Understand impact of innovation & creativity on organizations, institutions & society
2. Assess and look for ways to enhance your creativity, innovation and problem solving style to improve your performance.
3. Understand the impact of entrepreneurship & innovation on society
4. Understand alternative innovation strategies
5. Apply creativity theories to the creative problem solving process
6. Apply creativity tools to identify problems
7. Evaluate entrepreneurial and innovative opportunities using formal innovation assessment tools
8. Understand the challenges associated with implementing innovative ideas
Identify and describe the importance and impact of entrepreneurship & innovation on organizations, institutions and society
Understand how to build your personal creativity machine.
Able to exemplify the impact of entrepreneurship and innovation on society.
Able to define and apply alternative innovation strategies.
Apply the creative problem solving process in a variety of contexts.
Integrate design thinking and other problem identification tools to establish critical problems/opportunities.
Use an assessment tool to identify and choose between different innovation opportunities/solutions.
Appreciate the challenges of implementing innovative ideas.

title: Data Management Systems
description: DIGT 3107 convers concepts, approaches, and techniques in data management systems. Topics include logical models of relational databases, relational database design, query languages, crash recovery, and concurrency control. The purpose of this course is to introduce the fundamental concepts of database management, including aspects of data models, database languages, and database design. At the end of this course, a student will be able to understand and apply the fundamental concepts required for the design and administration of data management systems. Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 2102 8.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 3201 3.00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Students will learn about properties of structured data and relational database management systems.
Students will learn about database design at conceptual and logical levels of utilizing entity relationships (ER) models.
Students will learn about development of relational database schemas which enforce data integrity represented in ER models and comply with Boyce-Codd Normal Form.
Students will learn about properties of semi-structured and unstructured data management such as XML and NoSQL.
Students will learn about use of Structured Query Language (SQL) to implement relational database schemas, create and manipulate tables, indexes, and views.
Students will learn about database application programs with an understanding of transaction management, concurrency control, and crash recovery.
Students will learn about approaches for modeling and managing data for large scale systems.
CLO1: Interpret  properties of structured data and relational database management systems.
CLO2: Model databases proficiently at conceptual and logical levels of design with entity relationships (ER).
CLO3: Develop relational database schemas which enforce data integrity represented in ER models and comply with Boyce-Codd Normal Form.
CLO4: Interpret properties of semi-structured and unstructured documents and databases.
CLO5: Implement a relational database schema using Structured Query Language: create and manipulate tables, indexes, and views.
CLO6: Develop database application programs with an understanding of transaction management, concurrency control, and crash recovery.
CLO7: Compare various data modelling approaches for large scale systems.

title: Introduction to Project Management
description:
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practices of project management, specifically tailored for software development projects. Covering the entire project lifecycle from initiation and planning to execution, monitoring, control, and closure, it emphasizes the unique challenges and methodologies of software projects. Key topics include project scope, time management, cost estimation, quality assurance, risk management, and stakeholder communication. Students gain hands-on experience with industry-standard tools such as Jira, Trello, and Git for project tracking, version control, and collaboration. The course also explores Agile and Scrum methodologies, emphasizing iterative development and continuous improvement.
 
By the end of the course, students will be able to develop project plans, manage timelines, allocate resources effectively, and mitigate potential risks in software development. They will be proficient in using tools like Jira for project tracking and collaboration.

Pre-requisites: LE/DIGT 1161 2.00. Course credit exclusions: LE/CSSD 4103 3.00
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Digital Technologies (DIGT) - Lassonde School of Engineering

outcomes.value: Students will gain a thorough understanding of the key concepts and principles of project management, particularly in software development.
Students will be capable of creating detailed project plans that include scope, scheduling, cost, quality, risk management, and feasibility analysis.
Students will learn to effectively use project management tools like Jira, Trello, and Git for planning, tracking, and collaboration.
Students will develop skills to efficiently manage project timelines and resources to ensure timely completion.
Students will enhance their communication skills to manage stakeholder expectations and align projects with organizational goals.
Students will adapt and apply Agile and Scrum methodologies to various software development environments.
CLO1: Describe the key concepts and principles of project management in the context of software development projects.
CLO2: Develop comprehensive project plans that include scope, schedule, cost, quality, risk management strategies, and feasibility analysis.
CLO3: Utilize project management tools to effectively plan, track, and monitor projects.
CLO4: Manage project timelines and resources efficiently and communicate effectively to ensure timely completion of software development projects.
CLO5: Apply Agile and Scrum methodologies to meet the needs of different software development projects.
CLO6: Reflect on the learnings on project management in the context of student’s workplace experience.

title: Electric Vehicles
description: This course introduces the electric vehicles (EV) fundamentals, types, and technologies of their constituent components. It covers the environmental impacts of electrified transportation and describes the methods for deriving the EV dynamics and the characteristics and parameters of the EV energy storage systems, powertrains, and charging systems. The EV integration with modern power systems, i.e., smart grids and microgrids, is demonstrated, and important unidirectional and bi-directional (V2G) charging aspects are also discussed. Prerequisite: LE/EECS 2210 3.00 or LE/EECS 3505 3.00 or LE/EECS 3603 .00.
_searchableSubjectCodeDescriptions: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) - Lassonde School of Engineering
